title: This is a Blog post about brush strokes
subtitle: To combat such crimes, a number of best practices have sprung up as the field of data visualisation has matured. From steering clear of pie charts to getting rid of “chartjunk”, these are the conventions anyone dabbling in data viz should learn first.

content.content: It’s easy to visualise data badly. Choose the wrong chart type, omit labels or overload the graphic and you can quickly end up with aln⁡(x2)lim⁡x→∞a \frac{\ln(x^2)}{\lim_{x \to\infty}}alimx→∞​ln(x2)​ something that is confusing, misleading or that fails to tell a story. To combat such crimes, a number of best practices have sprung up as the field of data visualisation has matured. From steering clear of pie charts to getting rid of “chartjunk”, these are the conventions anyone dabbling in data viz should learn first.
content.md:
It’s easy to visualise data badly. Choose the wrong chart type, omit labels or overload the graphic and you can quickly end up with $$a \frac{\ln(x^2)}{\lim_{x \to\infty}}$$ something that is confusing, misleading or that fails to tell a story. To combat such crimes, a number of best practices have sprung up as the field of data visualisation has matured. From steering clear of pie charts to getting rid of “chartjunk”, these are the conventions anyone dabbling in data viz should learn first.

> This is a Block Quotation. This is part two of that, which is much longer and makes it a long single line quotation, not like a poem which is usually multi-line. Below is a citation.
>:-Aldous Huxley, <cite>[Brave New World](https://developer.mozilla.org/)</cite>

content.caption: This is a caption that describes the image of the polar bear on the pen above. The polar bear here may represent some sort of person or job that is slowly going extinct. The pen here is the livelihood of the said person that the person depends on, and builds his or her life on top of. As the pen disappears, so does the hope of the persons future.
